sn47.25:4.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī, in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
sn47.25:4.3: Then a certain brahmin went up to the Buddha,
sn47.25:4.5: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side,
sn47.25:4.7: “What is the cause, Master Gotama, what is the reason why the true teaching does not last long after the final extinguishment of the Realized One?
sn47.25:4.8: And what is the cause, what is the reason why the true teaching does last long after the final extinguishment of the Realized One?”
sn47.25:5.1: “Brahmin, it’s because of not developing and cultivating the four kinds of mindfulness meditation that the true teaching doesn’t last long after the final extinguishment of the Realized One.
sn47.25:5.2: It’s because of developing and cultivating the four kinds of mindfulness meditation that the true teaching does last long after the final extinguishment of the Realized One.
sn47.25:6.2: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn47.25:6.3: They meditate by observing an aspect of feelings …
sn47.25:6.5: principles, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn47.25:6.6: It’s because of not developing and cultivating these four kinds of mindfulness meditation that the true teaching doesn’t last long after the final extinguishment of the Realized One.
sn47.25:6.7: It’s because of developing and cultivating these four kinds of mindfulness meditation that the true teaching does last long after the final extinguishment of the Realized One.”
sn47.25:7.1: When he said this, the brahmin said to the Buddha:
sn47.25:7.3: From this day forth, may Master Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
